addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

8 Au
g
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
Holtes
e Jesuistes letters intercepted.
The complaint against
S
r
Edward Norris
continued./

page.lettertext:
fol.272r
May it please yo
r
good L. there is nothing
more understoode of
e Enemies proceedinges, then
that w
ch
I writte in my last from
e
Hage,
That
some part of his forces are passed
e Maese,
e rest
as yet remaining about
Venlo
and
Ruremonde.
The
Duke
himself w
t
some companies of horse and
foote is gone to
e Spawe, having left
Verdugo
to
commaund in his absence. The forces of this
contrey lie continually in
e Betuwe, betweene
Waggeningen
and
Rhenen,
and doe not intend to
passe
e Wael, till they see
at the Enemie is fur-
ther removed. It doth appeare by certaine
letters, w
ch
we have newly intercepted, that the
Enemie is much moved w
t
his late losses in these
contreis, and conceaveth litle hope of his happy
successe in this sommers exploites. There
is one father Holt an Englishe Jesuit in their campe,
unto whome there were letters addressed in Englishe,
not contening any mater,
at is greatly worth
e
knowing, but yet discovering some fugitives and
their present intent to come for
England.
I have
sent heere inclosed
e original letters. I am
demaunded at this present by
e
Councel of state
,
what her
Ma
tie
hath resolved in the affaires of
Ostend.
For
M
r
Caron
doth certifie, that her
Hig
nes
intention hath bin signified unto me, and
that I have bin required to deale w
t
the states,
that Commissioners may be chosen of bothe sides, for
a final redresse of all their griefes. But as yet
I had no letter to any suche effect, nether from her
Ma
tie
nor from yo
r
L. nor any at all at any
time sins
e 18 day of June. Howbeit as in
several other letters I have written to yo
r
L.
it is greatly behoofull that some suche order should
be taken, and that very speedely. For the
fol.272v
States of Zeland
have written flatly to this coun-
cel, their letter bearing date
e 2 of this moneth,
that for as muche as they have not hitherto provided
for
e reformation of those abuses of
e Governo
r
of Ostend, they themselves will seeke some remedy.
But howe their meaning is to deale, I can not
yet advertise. Moreover I have bin told
that it hath bin said by some special persons of
e
states assembly at
e Hage,
at except
e Gover-
no
r
will relent, and keepe w
t
in
e boundes of
his commission from
e contrey, they will tolerat
no longer, but declare him rebel. And so I doe
assure my self, as I have alwaies signified in
all my letters to yo
r
L. that they will rather
proceede to termes of hostilitie, then be bridled
by
e governo
r
in
e administration of their
government. Wherein her Ma
ties
service is advantaged nowe, by these endevo
rs
,
of
e Governor, more then otherwise it might be,
by an ordinary meanes, w
t
e contreis appro-
bation, or lesse discontentment, I can not con-
jecture of my self, and truly as hitherto I have
bin privy to nothing by
e Governo
rs
infor-
mation. I protest unto yo
r
L. I doe not
affect in mine owne regard to knowe any
kinde of mater, that is not properly pertinent
to
e place where I am trusted, w
ch
I hold to
be sufficient, to keepe me busied in my charge.
Nevertheles I finde it very requisit, in affaires
of any moment, that no innovation should be
made by Governo
r
or other of her Ma
ties
mi-
nisters, but it should be first imparted, and so
practised or not practised, w
t
effectual cor-
respondence, w
t
whosoever shall be heere to
reside in councel for her Hig
nes
. For otherwise
fol.273r
be it said w
t
submission to yo
r
L. correction,
howsoever they are ledde w
t
apparance of good
courses, they may falle very easely into many
mistakinges, and suche great inconveniences, as
may prejudice her Ma
tie
and these contreis very
highly. Whiche I signifie thus boldly, provoked
therunto through
e great desire that I have, to
acquite my duty to her
Ma
tie
w
t
unfa in ed service, and
through my wonted confidence,
at yo
r
L. will
accept my speaking cleerely in suche causes.
And
so I take my humble leave. From Arnham.
Au
g
81591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
